spanishExample: ¡Trata de hacerlo! Si no, esto se acabará.
englishTranslation: Try to do it! If not, this will run out.
vocabIncluded: acabarse: any use of acabar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to run out)
acabará: will finish, he/she/it will finish (Acabar, future, 3rd person)
de used after Tratar to mean “try to”

spanishExample: ¿Por qué no tratas de llevarlo a tu casa?
englishTranslation: Why don’t you try to take it to your house?
vocabIncluded: de used after Tratar to mean “try to”
tratas: try, you try (Tratar, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Acaba de volver de ese lugar bonito.
englishTranslation: She has just returned from that pretty place.
vocabIncluded: acaba: finishes, he/she/it finishes (Acabar, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Acabamos de hablar con ella, pero ella trataba de irse.
englishTranslation: We just talked to her, but she was trying to leave.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
trataba: tried, I tried (Tratar, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: Acaban de ver el baño porque están tratando de poner cosas nuevas.
englishTranslation: They’ve just seen the bathroom because they're trying to put in new things.
vocabIncluded: acaban: finish, they finish (Acabar, present, 3rd person plural)
de used after Tratar to mean “try to”

spanishExample: Acabas de llegar y él acaba de irse.
englishTranslation: You just arrived and he just left.
vocabIncluded: acaba: finishes, he/she/it finishes (Acabar, present, 3rd person)
acabas: finish, you finish (Acabar, present, 2nd person)
irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: Acabas de tener un día perfecto y no te diste cuenta.
englishTranslation: You just had a perfect day and you didn't realize.
vocabIncluded: acabas: finish, you finish (Acabar, present, 2nd person)
darse cuenta de que: to realize (idiom)

spanishExample: Acabo de irme porque quiero que él trate de estar solo.
englishTranslation: I just left because I want him to try to be alone.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
acabo: finish, I finish (Acabar, present, 1st person)
de used after Tratar to mean “try to”
irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
trate: try, he/she/it try (Tratar, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: El agua se puede acabar.
englishTranslation: The water might run out.
vocabIncluded: acabarse: any use of acabar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to run out)

spanishExample: Ellos tratan de irse, pero nosotros acabamos de llegar.
englishTranslation: They’re trying to leave, but we have just arrived.
vocabIncluded: acabamos: finish, we finish (Acabar, present, 1st person plural)
de used after Tratar to mean “try to”
irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
tratan: try, they try (Tratar, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Estaba en la oficina, pero trataba de ver el cielo.
englishTranslation: I was at the office, but I was trying to see the sky.
vocabIncluded: de used after Tratar to mean “try to”
trataba: tried, I tried (Tratar, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: Iremos por más café cuando se acabe el que tenemos en casa.
englishTranslation: We’ll go for more coffee when the one we have at home runs out.
vocabIncluded: acabarse: any use of acabar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to run out)
acabe: finish, he/she/it finish (Acabar, subjunctive, 3rd person)
iremos: "will go", "we will go" (Ir, future, 1st person plural)
por used after Ir to mean _pick up_

spanishExample: La historia se trata de un perro y les parece graciosa.
englishTranslation: The story is about a dog and it seems funny to them.
vocabIncluded: les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
parece: seems, he/she/it seems (Parecer, present, 3rd person)
trata: tries, he/she/it tries (Tratar, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: La trato bien, pero ella me trata mal.
englishTranslation: I treat her well, but she treats me badly.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
trato: try, I try (Tratar, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Nada se puede acabar durante la fiesta.
englishTranslation: Nothing can run out during the party.
vocabIncluded: acabarse: any use of acabar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to run out)

spanishExample: Nos acaban de dar más.
englishTranslation: They just gave us more.
vocabIncluded: acaban: finish, they finish (Acabar, present, 3rd person plural)
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: Pobre perro, tratamos de llevarlo a casa.
englishTranslation: Poor dog, we tried to bring him home.
vocabIncluded: tratamos: tried, we tried (Tratar, preterite, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Quiero que trate de buscar al perro más lindo de todos.
englishTranslation: I want him to try to look for the cutest dog of all.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
al: "to the" before a masculine noun
de used after Tratar to mean “try to”
de used to single something out from a group, as in “él más grande del grupo”
trate: try, he/she/it try (Tratar, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Se acabaron esos bienes y ahora tratamos de buscar más.
englishTranslation: Those goods ran out and now we’re trying to look for more.
vocabIncluded: acabaron: finished, they finished (Acabar, preterite, 3rd person plural)
acabarse: any use of acabar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to run out)
de used after Tratar to mean “try to”
tratamos: try, we try (Tratar, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Se acabaron todas las ideas y trató de pensar en más.
englishTranslation: All the ideas ran out and he tried to think of more.
vocabIncluded: acabaron: finished, they finished (Acabar, preterite, 3rd person plural)
acabarse: any use of acabar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to run out)
de used after Tratar to mean “try to”
trató: tried, he/she/it tried (Tratar, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Se acabó lo que necesitábamos y ella ha tratado de buscar más.
englishTranslation: What we needed ran out and she has tried to look for more.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
acabarse: any use of acabar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to run out)
acabó: finished, he/she/it finished (Acabar, preterite, 3rd person)
de used after Tratar to mean “try to”
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
necesitábamos: needed, we needed (Necesitar, imperfect, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Se le acabará su comida pronto.
englishTranslation: His food will run out soon.
vocabIncluded: acabarse: any use of acabar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to run out)
acabó: finished, he/she/it finished (Acabar, preterite, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Se le ha acabado el agua.
englishTranslation: The water has run out.
vocabIncluded: acabarse: any use of acabar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to run out)
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Tienes que tratar de pasar por ese edificio, yo acabo de estar ahí.
englishTranslation: You have to try to pass by that building, I was just there.
vocabIncluded: acabo: finish, I finish (Acabar, present, 1st person)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
de used after Tratar to mean “try to”
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Todavía no se acabó el café. Voy a buscar más cuando se acabe.
englishTranslation: The coffee didn’t run out yet. I’ll look for more when it runs out.
vocabIncluded: acabarse: any use of acabar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to run out)
acabe: finish, he/she/it finish (Acabar, subjunctive, 3rd person)
acabó: finished, he/she/it finished (Acabar, preterite, 3rd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Traté de ir a ese lugar porque me dijeron que era muy bello.
englishTranslation: I tried to go to that place because they told me it was very beautiful.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
de used after Tratar to mean “try to”
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
traté: tried, I tried (Tratar, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Ya se ha acabado la música.
englishTranslation: The music is now over (lit “has run out”).
vocabIncluded: acabarse: any use of acabar with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to run out)
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: Yo trataré de ir pronto.
englishTranslation: I’ll try to go soon.
vocabIncluded: de used after Tratar to mean “try to”
trataré: will try , I will try (Tratar, future, 1st person)
